messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Peter Morgan <pmorgan@j...> wrote:
> On Thu, 2003-07-24 at 19:15, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > For some odd reason I don't like setting expectations on an object
then letting it verify itself. Sounds weird. I prefer to be the one to
verify it. I don't know why.
>
> I agree. I have been mocking for some 5 years now (in our group we
> originally called them crash test dummies).

We often use that phrase when describing them to students.

> I much prefer to query the mock object and assert whether the
> 'correct' thing happened in the unit test.

Hmm.. not very object opriented. Why not tell the mock what to
expect, and let it figure out if it happened?

Then you have a specification of the interaction in your test... not
just the postconditions.

How do you test for correct call sequencing?

Both approaches have their place. To me it depends on whether I want
to test interaction or results.

> We sell a dynamic mock object implementation that works for
> non-final classes and interfaces using byte code modification, that
> we call 'imposter'.

Interesting. Why? (i.e. why sell and why that approach)

> You can also download a GPL code coverage tool from us too.

I'll have to look into it. I've been hooked on Clover for a while now.

Dave
